meanings.def: the back part of the foot below the ankle
examples: Apply the cream to dry, cracked heels before bed.
on your heels She took a potato from the fire and sat back on her heels.
The punch rocked him back on his heels.
Despite severe pain from a badly bruised heel, he ran the race of his life.

meanings.def: the part of a sock, etc. that covers the heel
the raised part on the bottom of a shoe, boot, etc. that makes the shoe, etc. higher at the back
examples: shoes with a low/high heel
a stiletto heel
He crushed the cigarette under the heel of his shoe.
The sergeant clicked his heels and walked out.
Salt can heal wounds.
Her heel caught in the stairs and she tumbled down.
He'll arrive in a minute!
She caught her heel and tripped on the step.
I took my shoes to a heel bar to have them repaired.

meanings.def: having the type of heel mentioned
examples: high-heeled shoes

meanings.def: a pair of shoes that have high heels
examples: She doesn't often wear heels.
I had to do the whole walk in heels.

meanings.def: the raised part of the inside of the hand where it joins the wrist
a man who is unpleasant to other people and cannot be trusted
following closely behind somebody
examples: He fled from the stadium with the police at his heels.
She came up the path with two little dogs at her heels.

meanings.def: to force somebody to obey you and accept discipline
examples: a non-violent means of bringing the rebels to heel

meanings.def: to make a dog come close to you
to agree to obey somebody and accept their orders
to come close to the person who has called it
to have to wait for somebody/something
to refuse to do something or to change your mind about something
examples: They dug in their heels and would not lower the price.

meanings.def: to be deliberately slow in doing something or in making a decision
very close behind somebody/something; very soon after something
examples: He turned and fled with Peter hot on his heels.
They reached the border with the police hot on their heels.
Further successes came hot on the heels of her first best-selling novel.
News of rising unemployment followed hard on the heels of falling export figures.

meanings.def: loving somebody very much
examples: He's fallen head over heels in love with his boss.

meanings.def: to have nothing to do while you are waiting for somebody/something
examples: We were kicking our heels, waiting for some customers.

meanings.def: to be relaxed and enjoy yourself
to run away from somebody/something
to follow somebody closely
to turn around suddenly so that you are facing in the opposite direction
examples: He turned on his heel and marched away angrily.

meanings.def: completely controlled by somebody
examples: The island spent several centuries under the heel of the British Empire.
